title: Hestia Criteria for Outpatient Pulmonary Embolism Treatment
description: Identifies low-risk pulmonary embolism patients who may be safe for outpatient management. The criteria assess clinical stability, bleeding risk, social factors, and comorbidities to determine suitability for home treatment.

parameters.name: hemodynamically_unstable
parameters.description: Hemodynamically unstable (sBP <100 mmHg and HR >100 bpm; or condition requiring ICU admission)

parameters.name: active_bleeding
parameters.description: Active bleeding or high risk for bleeding

parameters.name: oxygen_24hr
parameters.description: >24 hrs on supplemental oxygen required to maintain oxygen saturation >90%

parameters.name: severe_pain_iv_meds
parameters.description: Severe pain needing IV pain medication >24 hr

parameters.name: medical_social_reason
parameters.description: Medical or social reason for admission >24 hr (infection, malignancy, no support system)

ranges.interpretation: Patient meets criteria for outpatient management. Associated with 0% mortality and 2% VTE recurrence rate. Consider for home treatment with appropriate anticoagulation and close follow-up.
Patient has ≥1 exclusion criteria and should be considered for inpatient management. Hospitalization recommended for closer monitoring and treatment.

references: Zondag W, Mos IC, Creemers-Schild D, Mulder JW, Herb-van Toumhout SJ, Hovens MM, et al.; Hestia Study Investigators. Outpatient treatment in patients with acute pulmonary embolism: the Hestia Study. J Thromb Haemost. 2011 Aug;9(8):1500-7.

Zondag W, den Exter PL, Crobach MJ, Dolsma A, Donker ML, Eijsvogel M, et al.; Hestia Study Investigators. Comparison of two methods for selection of out of hospital treatment in patients with acute pulmonary embolism. Thromb Haemost. 2013 Jan;109(1):47-52.
formula: Score = Sum of all 'yes' responses (0 = low risk, ≥1 = not low risk)
notes: Designed for hemodynamically stable PE patients only
All criteria must be 'no' for patient to be considered low risk
Requires careful patient counseling about treatment risks and warning signs
Associated with decreased hospital stay and lower healthcare costs
Should be used in conjunction with clinical judgment
